The number of constant multiplications required in Step 2 can also be reduced by exploiting two-input multiplexers. We can observe that

𝐌𝐮𝐥p​t​(𝐑𝐨𝐭​([𝐀(0)]p​k,k−h),𝐯k−h)=𝐑𝐨𝐭​(𝐌𝐮𝐥p​t​([𝐀(0)]p​k,𝐑​(𝐯k−h,h−k)),k−h)=𝐑𝐨𝐭​([𝐀(0)]p​k−𝐌𝐮𝐥p​t​([𝐀(0)]p​k,𝐑​(𝐯k,−k)),k−h)subscript𝐌𝐮𝐥𝑝𝑡𝐑𝐨𝐭subscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝐀0𝑝𝑘𝑘ℎsubscript𝐯𝑘ℎ𝐑𝐨𝐭subscript𝐌𝐮𝐥𝑝𝑡subscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝐀0𝑝𝑘𝐑subscript𝐯𝑘ℎℎ𝑘𝑘ℎ𝐑𝐨𝐭subscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝐀0𝑝𝑘subscript𝐌𝐮𝐥𝑝𝑡subscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝐀0𝑝𝑘𝐑subscript𝐯𝑘𝑘𝑘ℎ\begin{split}&\mathbf{Mul}_{pt}(\mathbf{Rot}([\mathbf{A}^{(0)}]_{pk},k-h),\mathbf{v}_{k-h})\\ &=\mathbf{Rot}(\mathbf{Mul}_{pt}([\mathbf{A}^{(0)}]_{pk},\mathbf{R}(\mathbf{v}_{k-h},h-k)),k-h)\\ &=\mathbf{Rot}([\mathbf{A}^{(0)}]_{pk}-\mathbf{Mul}_{pt}([\mathbf{A}^{(0)}]_{pk},\mathbf{R}(\mathbf{v}_{k},-k)),k-h)\end{split}

Then, we can first compute 𝐌𝐮𝐥p​t​([𝐀(0)]p​k,𝐑​(𝐯k,−k))subscript𝐌𝐮𝐥𝑝𝑡subscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝐀0𝑝𝑘𝐑subscript𝐯𝑘𝑘\mathbf{Mul}_{pt}([\mathbf{A}^{(0)}]_{pk},\mathbf{R}(\mathbf{v}_{k},-k)) for each 1≤k<h1𝑘ℎ1\leq k<h. Based on the fact that

𝐌𝐮𝐥p​t​(𝐑𝐨𝐭​([𝐀(0)]p​k,k),𝐯k)=𝐑𝐨𝐭​(𝐌𝐮𝐥p​t​([𝐀(0)]p​k,𝐑​(𝐯k,−k)),k)subscript𝐌𝐮𝐥𝑝𝑡𝐑𝐨𝐭subscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝐀0𝑝𝑘𝑘subscript𝐯𝑘𝐑𝐨𝐭subscript𝐌𝐮𝐥𝑝𝑡subscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝐀0𝑝𝑘𝐑subscript𝐯𝑘𝑘𝑘\begin{split}\mathbf{Mul}_{pt}(\mathbf{Rot}([\mathbf{A}^{(0)}]_{pk},k),\mathbf{v}_{k})=\mathbf{Rot}(\mathbf{Mul}_{pt}([\mathbf{A}^{(0)}]_{pk},\mathbf{R}(\mathbf{v}_{k},-k)),k)\end{split}

we can get the ciphertext [𝐀(k)]p​ksubscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝐀𝑘𝑝𝑘[\mathbf{A}^{(k)}]_{pk} with addition and rotation operations.

Appendix C Matrix Transposition on Packed Ciphertexts

In this section, we introduce how to homomorphically transpose a matrix under the packed ciphertext. Let 𝐚=ι−1​(A)∈Rn𝐚superscript𝜄1𝐴superscript𝑅𝑛\mathbf{a}=\iota^{-1}(A)\in R^{n} indicate the vector representation of a matrix A𝐴A, UTsuperscript𝑈𝑇U^{T} is defined as the matrix representation of the transpose map A↦ATmaps-to𝐴superscript𝐴𝑇A\mapsto A^{T} on Rh×h≅Rnsuperscript𝑅ℎℎsuperscript𝑅𝑛R^{h\times h}\cong R^{n}. Then, for 0≤i,j<hformulae-sequence0𝑖𝑗ℎ0\leq i,j<h, each element in UTsuperscript𝑈𝑇U^{T} can be expressed as

Uh⋅i+j,kT={1​𝗂𝖿​k=h⋅j+i;0​𝗈𝗍𝗁𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝗌𝖾.{U}_{h\cdot i+j,k}^{T}=\left\{\begin{aligned} &1\quad\mathsf{if}\;k=h\cdot j+i;\\ &0\quad\mathsf{otherwise}.\\ \end{aligned}\right.

Hence, the k𝑘k-th diagonal vector of UTsuperscript𝑈𝑇U^{T} is nonzero if and only if k=(h−1)⋅i𝑘⋅ℎ1𝑖k=(h-1)\cdot i for some i∈ℤ∩(−h,h)𝑖ℤℎℎi\in\mathbb{Z}\cap(-h,h). As a result, UTsuperscript𝑈𝑇U^{T} has a total of (2​h−1)2ℎ1(2h-1) nonzero diagonal vectors as a sparse matrix. Therefore, linear transformation for matrix transpose can be expressed as

UT⋅𝐚=∑−h<i<h(𝐭(h−1)⋅i⊙𝐑​(𝐚,(h−1)⋅i))⋅superscript𝑈𝑇𝐚subscriptℎ𝑖ℎdirect-productsubscript𝐭⋅ℎ1𝑖𝐑𝐚⋅ℎ1𝑖\begin{split}U^{T}\cdot\mathbf{a}=\sum_{-h<i<h}(\mathbf{t}_{(h-1)\cdot i}\odot\mathbf{R}(\mathbf{a},(h-1)\cdot i))\end{split} (18)

where we use 𝐭(h−1)⋅isubscript𝐭⋅ℎ1𝑖\mathbf{t}_{(h-1)\cdot i} to represent the nonzero diagonal vector of UTsuperscript𝑈𝑇U^{T}. When i≥0𝑖0i\geq 0, the t𝑡t-th component of the vector 𝐭(h−1)⋅isubscript𝐭⋅ℎ1𝑖\mathbf{t}_{(h-1)\cdot i} is computed by

𝐭(h−1)⋅i[t]={1​𝗂𝖿​t−i=(h+1)⋅j,0≤j<h−i;0​𝗈𝗍𝗁𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝗌𝖾.\mathbf{t}_{(h-1)\cdot i}[t]=\left\{\begin{aligned} &1\quad\mathsf{if}\;t-i=(h+1)\cdot j,0\leq j<h-i;\\ &0\quad\mathsf{otherwise}.\\ \end{aligned}\right.

If i≤0𝑖0i\leq 0, we have

𝐭(h−1)⋅i[t]={1​𝗂𝖿​t+i=(h+1)⋅j,0≤j<h+i;0​𝗈𝗍𝗁𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝗌𝖾.\mathbf{t}_{(h-1)\cdot i}[t]=\left\{\begin{aligned} &1\quad\mathsf{if}\;t+i=(h+1)\cdot j,0\leq j<h+i;\\ &0\quad\mathsf{otherwise}.\\ \end{aligned}\right.

In general, the computation cost required for matrix transposition is about 2​h2ℎ2h rotations, which can be further reduced to 3​h3ℎ3\sqrt{h} by the previously described baby-step/giant-step method.

Appendix D Rectangular Matrix Multiplication on Packed Ciphertexts

We extend the homomorphic multiplication between square matrices to general rectangular matrices, such as Rt×h×Rh×h→Rt×h→superscript𝑅𝑡ℎsuperscript𝑅ℎℎsuperscript𝑅𝑡ℎR^{t\times h}\times R^{h\times h}\rightarrow R^{t\times h} or Rh×h×Rh×t→Rh×t→superscript𝑅ℎℎsuperscript𝑅ℎ𝑡superscript𝑅ℎ𝑡R^{h\times h}\times R^{h\times t}\rightarrow R^{h\times t}. Without loss of generality, we consider t<h𝑡ℎt<h. For a (h1×h)subscriptℎ1ℎ(h_{1}\times h)-dimensional matrix A1subscript𝐴1A_{1} and a (h2×h)subscriptℎ2ℎ(h_{2}\times h)-dimensional matrix A2subscript𝐴2A_{2}, we use (A1;A2)subscript𝐴1subscript𝐴2(A_{1};A_{2}) to represent the (h1+h2)×hsubscriptℎ1subscriptℎ2ℎ(h_{1}+h_{2})\times h matrix which is obtained by concatenating A1subscript𝐴1A_{1} and A2subscript𝐴2A_{2} in a vertical direction. Similarly, (A1|A2)conditionalsubscript𝐴1subscript𝐴2(A_{1}|A_{2}) indicates the matrix concatenated in a horizontal direction if matrices A1subscript𝐴1A_{1} and A2subscript𝐴2A_{2} have the same number of rows.

A naive solution to perform multiplication between rectangular matrices is to convert any matrix into a square matrix through zero padding, and then use Algorithm 3 to implement the multiplication between square matrices homomorphically. This leads to a rotation with a complexity of O​(h)𝑂ℎO(h). We provide an improved method through insight into the property of matrix permutation.
Refined Rectangular Matrix Multiplication. Given a t×h𝑡ℎt\times h matrix A𝐴A and an h×hℎℎh\times h matrix B𝐵B with t𝑡t divide hℎh, we introduce a new symbol Ct1:t2subscript𝐶:subscript𝑡1subscript𝑡2C_{t_{1}:t_{2}}, which is denoted the (t2−t1)×hsubscript𝑡2subscript𝑡1ℎ(t_{2}-t_{1})\times h submatrix of C𝐶C formed by extracting from t1subscript𝑡1t_{1}-th row to the (t2−1)subscript𝑡21(t_{2}-1)-th row of C𝐶C. As a result, the product of A​B𝐴𝐵AB can be expressed as below.

A⋅B=∑k=0h−1(ϕk∘μ​(A))⊙((πk∘ζ​(B))0:t)=∑0≤i<t∑0≤j<h/t(ϕj⋅t+i∘μ​(A))⊙((πj⋅t+i∘ζ​(B))0:t)⋅𝐴𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑘0ℎ1direct-productsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘𝜇𝐴subscriptsuperscript𝜋𝑘𝜁𝐵:0𝑡subscript0𝑖𝑡subscript0𝑗ℎ𝑡direct-productsuperscriptitalic-ϕ⋅𝑗𝑡𝑖𝜇𝐴subscriptsuperscript𝜋⋅𝑗𝑡𝑖𝜁𝐵:0𝑡\begin{split}A\cdot B&=\sum_{k=0}^{h-1}(\phi^{k}\circ\mu(A))\odot\left((\pi^{k}\circ\zeta(B))_{0:t}\right)\\ &=\sum_{0\leq i<t}\sum_{0\leq j<h/t}(\phi^{j\cdot t+i}\circ\mu(A))\odot\left((\pi^{j\cdot t+i}\circ\zeta(B))_{0:t}\right)\end{split} (19)

Our key observation is the following lemma, which provides us with ideas for designing fast rectangular matrix multiplication.

Lemma D.1.

Permutation ϕitalic-ϕ\phi and μ𝜇\mu are commutative. For k>0𝑘0k>0, we have ϕk∘μ=μ∘ϕksuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘𝜇𝜇superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘\phi^{k}\circ\mu=\mu\circ\phi^{k}. Also, πk∘ζ=ζ∘πksuperscript𝜋𝑘𝜁𝜁superscript𝜋𝑘\pi^{k}\circ\zeta=\zeta\circ\pi^{k} for k>0𝑘0k>0.

Based on Lemma D.1, we define an h×hℎℎh\times h-dimensional matrix A~~𝐴\tilde{A}, which contains h/tℎ𝑡h/t copies of A𝐴A from the vertical direction (i.e., A~=(A;⋯;A)~𝐴𝐴⋯𝐴\tilde{A}=(A;\cdots;A)). It means that

(ϕi∘μ​(A~))j⋅t:(j+1)⋅t=(ϕi∘μ​(A~)j⋅t:(j+1)⋅t)=ϕi∘μ∘ϕj⋅t​(A)=ϕj⋅t+i∘μ​(A)subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝜇~𝐴:⋅𝑗𝑡⋅𝑗1𝑡superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝜇subscript~𝐴:⋅𝑗𝑡⋅𝑗1𝑡superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝜇superscriptitalic-ϕ⋅𝑗𝑡𝐴superscriptitalic-ϕ⋅𝑗𝑡𝑖𝜇𝐴\begin{split}(\phi^{i}\circ\mu(\tilde{A}))_{j\cdot t:(j+1)\cdot t}&=(\phi^{i}\circ\mu(\tilde{A})_{j\cdot t:(j+1)\cdot t})\\ &=\phi^{i}\circ\mu\circ\phi^{j\cdot t}(A)\\ &=\phi^{j\cdot t+i}\circ\mu(A)\end{split} (20)

Then, we can further compute

(πi∘ζ​(B))j⋅t:(j+1)⋅t=(πj⋅t+i∘ζ​(B))0:tsubscriptsuperscript𝜋𝑖𝜁𝐵:⋅𝑗𝑡⋅𝑗1𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜋⋅𝑗𝑡𝑖𝜁𝐵:0𝑡\begin{split}(\pi^{i}\circ\zeta({B}))_{j\cdot t:(j+1)\cdot t}=(\pi^{j\cdot t+i}\circ\zeta(B))_{0:t}\end{split} (21)

As a result, the matrix product A​B𝐴𝐵AB can be rewritten as below.

A⋅B=∑0≤j<h/t(∑0≤i<t(ϕi∘μ​(A~))⊙(πi∘ζ​(B)))j⋅t:(j+1)⋅t⋅𝐴𝐵subscript0𝑗ℎ𝑡subscriptsubscript0𝑖𝑡direct-productsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝜇~𝐴superscript𝜋𝑖𝜁𝐵:⋅𝑗𝑡⋅𝑗1𝑡\begin{split}A\cdot B=\sum_{0\leq j<h/t}\left(\sum_{0\leq i<t}(\phi^{i}\circ\mu(\tilde{A}))\odot(\pi^{i}\circ\zeta({B}))\right)_{j\cdot t:(j+1)\cdot t}\end{split}

Homomorphic Rectangular Matrix Multiplication. Given two ciphertexts [𝐀~]p​ksubscriptdelimited-[]~𝐀𝑝𝑘[\mathbf{\tilde{A}}]_{pk} and [𝐁]p​ksubscriptdelimited-[]𝐁𝑝𝑘[\mathbf{{B}}]_{pk}, we can first compute μ​(A~)𝜇~𝐴\mu{(\tilde{A})} and ζ​(B)𝜁𝐵\zeta({B}) utilizing the baay-step/giant-step approach. Then, ∑0≤i<t(ϕi∘μ​(A~))⊙(πi∘ζ​(B))subscript0𝑖𝑡direct-productsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝜇~𝐴superscript𝜋𝑖𝜁𝐵\sum_{0\leq i<t}(\phi^{i}\circ\mu(\tilde{A}))\odot(\pi^{i}\circ\zeta({B})) can be securely computed in a similar way to Algorithm 3. Finally, we get the encryption of A​B𝐴𝐵{A}B by performing aggregation and rotations operations. The details are shown in Algorithm V.

Table V presents the total complexity of Algorithm 6. We observe that compared with Algorithm 3, it reduces the complexity of the rotation operations of steps 2 and 3 to O​(t)𝑂𝑡O(t), although additional operation is required for step 4. Moreover, the final result [𝐀𝐁]p​ksubscriptdelimited-[]𝐀𝐁𝑝𝑘[\mathbf{AB}]_{pk} is a ciphertext of a h×hℎℎh\times h-dimensional matrix containing (h/t)ℎ𝑡(h/t) copies of the expected matrix product A​B𝐴𝐵AB in a vertical direction. Hence, the resulting ciphertext remains the format as a rectangular matrix, and it can be further performed matrix calculations without additional overhead.

Appendix E Parallel Matrix Computation

The above matrix operations are all performed in the message space Rnsuperscript𝑅𝑛R^{n}, where we assume that n=h2𝑛superscriptℎ2n=h^{2}. Actually, most HE schemes have a lot of plaintext slots (up to thousands) compared to the dimension of the matrix in deep learning, that is, usually n≫h2much-greater-than𝑛superscriptℎ2n\gg h^{2}. Hence, most plaintext slots will be wasted if a ciphertext is only used to store a matrix. We provide a method of encrypting multiple matrices into a ciphertext, so as to realize parallel matrix calculation in a SIMD manner. Specifically, we assume that n𝑛n is divisible by hℎh and let β=n/h2𝛽𝑛superscriptℎ2\beta=n/h^{2}. Then the encoding map described in above for singe matrix will be modified as ιβ:Rn→(Rh×h)β:subscript𝜄𝛽→superscript𝑅𝑛superscriptsuperscript𝑅ℎℎ𝛽\iota_{\beta}:R^{n}\rightarrow(R^{h\times h})^{\beta}. For an input vector 𝐚=(at)0≤t<n𝐚subscriptsubscript𝑎𝑡0𝑡𝑛\mathbf{a}=(a_{t})_{0\leq t<n}, ιβsubscript𝜄𝛽\iota_{\beta} is defined as below.

ιβ:𝐚↦(Ak=(aβ​(h⋅i+j)+k))0≤k<β.:subscript𝜄𝛽maps-to𝐚subscriptsubscript𝐴𝑘subscript𝑎𝛽⋅ℎ𝑖𝑗𝑘0𝑘𝛽\begin{split}\iota_{\beta}:\mathbf{a}\mapsto\left(A_{k}=(a_{\beta(h\cdot i+j)+k})\right)_{0\leq k<\beta}.\end{split} (22)

The components of 𝐚𝐚\mathbf{a} with indexes congruent to k𝑘k modulo β𝛽\beta are corresponding to the k𝑘k-th matrix Aksubscript𝐴𝑘A_{k}. We observe that for an integer 0≤t<h20𝑡superscriptℎ20\leq t<h^{2}, the rotation operation 𝐑​(𝐚,β​t)𝐑𝐚𝛽𝑡\mathbf{R}(\mathbf{a},\beta t) represents the matrix-wise rotation by β𝛽\beta positions. This can be naturally extended to other operations including scalar linear conversion and matrix multiplication. For example, when a single ciphertext is embedded in β𝛽\beta (h×hℎℎh\times h)-dimensional matrices, we can immediately perform matrix multiplication between β𝛽\beta pairs matrices by using the previously described algorithm on two ciphertexts. This total computation complexity is consistent with Algorithm 3, but results in a less amortized computation complexity of O​(h/β)𝑂ℎ𝛽O(h/\beta) for each matrix.

Appendix F Proof of Lemma  4.1

Proof (Sketch).

We use induction to prove it. First, it is true for n=1. Assume that pd=2​d+14d​(2​dd)subscript𝑝𝑑2𝑑1superscript4𝑑matrix2𝑑𝑑p_{d}=\frac{2d+1}{4^{d}}\begin{pmatrix}2d\\ d\end{pmatrix} for some d≤1𝑑1d\leq 1, Hence, we have

pd+1=pd+14d+1​(2​d+2d+1)=14d+1​(2​(2​d+2)!(d+1)!​d!+(2​d+2)!(d+1)!​(d+1)!)=2​d+34d+1​(2​d+2d+1)subscript𝑝𝑑1subscript𝑝𝑑1superscript4𝑑1matrix2𝑑2𝑑11superscript4𝑑122𝑑2𝑑1𝑑2𝑑2𝑑1𝑑12𝑑3superscript4𝑑1matrix2𝑑2𝑑1\begin{split}p_{d+1}&=p_{d}+\frac{1}{4^{d+1}}\begin{pmatrix}2d+2\\ d+1\end{pmatrix}\\ &=\frac{1}{4^{d+1}}\left(\frac{2(2d+2)!}{(d+1)!d!}+\frac{(2d+2)!}{(d+1)!(d+1)!}\right)\\ &=\frac{2d+3}{4^{d+1}}\begin{pmatrix}2d+2\\ d+1\end{pmatrix}\end{split}

Hence, the lemma is proved by induction. ∎

Appendix H Proof of Lemma  4.3

Proof (Sketch).

Let y=1−m𝑦1𝑚y=1-m, and define

Appendix I Experimental comparisons with work [34]

TABLE VI shows the running times of work [34] and our method for approximation of the sign function, where δ𝛿\delta is used to represent the error bound, i.e., 2−σsuperscript2𝜎2^{-\sigma} means that the value error of the original function and the approximated function is small than 2−σsuperscript2𝜎2^{-\sigma}, 𝒩=214𝒩superscript214\mathcal{N}=2^{14} and Qℒ=22250subscript𝑄ℒsuperscript22250Q_{\mathcal{L}}=2^{2250}. We observe that the running time of our method is much smaller than that of [34]. For example, the amortized running time of [34] to obtain the approximate result of sign function within 2−20superscript2202^{-20} errors is 668.9 milliseconds (amortized running time), while the running time of our method is only 20.05 milliseconds, which is 333333 times faster than [34].

Appendix J Details Implementation of Hercules

Figure 5 presents the details of implementing Hercules, which essentially executes Algorithm 1 under the ciphertext. Note that we assume that all matrices involved in training have the same dimensions for simplicity. In actual implementation, the user can adaptively select the dimension so as to use Algorithm  3 or 6 to obtain the ciphertext result. 𝐑𝐒​(⋅)𝐑𝐒⋅\mathbf{RS}(\cdot) is used to resulting ciphertext after each multiplication. This means that for the ciphertext with an initial layer number of ℒℒ\mathcal{L}, the maximum depth of ℒℒ\mathcal{L} ciphertext multiplication can be evaluated. In practical applications, assuming Qℒ/Δ=rsubscript𝑄ℒΔ𝑟Q_{\mathcal{L}}/\Delta=r, the ciphertext can be rescaled after r𝑟r multiplications instead of after each multiplication. On the other hand, Figure 5 only requires each user to perform the distributed bootstrapping function (i.e., 𝐃𝐁𝐨𝐨𝐭𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐚𝐩𝐃𝐁𝐨𝐨𝐭𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐚𝐩\mathbf{DBootstrap}) when calculating the activation function, because this process usually requires more circuit depth. Similarly, in practice, users can adaptively execute 𝐃𝐁𝐨𝐨𝐭𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐚𝐩𝐃𝐁𝐨𝐨𝐭𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐚𝐩\mathbf{DBootstrap} as long as the depth of the circuit is about to be exhausted.

Appendix K Datasets Used in Experiments

Consistent with POSEIDON [12], we choose the following public datasets in our experiments.

  • a.

    The Breast Cancer Wisconsin dataset (BCW) [45], which has a total of |D|=699𝐷699|D|=699 samples, and the dimension of each sample is h=9ℎ9h=9, with ω𝕃=2subscript𝜔𝕃2\omega_{\mathbb{L}}=2, where ω𝕃subscript𝜔𝕃\omega_{\mathbb{L}} represents the number of labels (also the number of neurons in the last layer of the neural network (NN)).

  • b.

    MNIST dataset [46] with |D|=70,000𝐷70000|D|=70,000, h=28×28ℎ2828h=28\times 28, and ω𝕃=10subscript𝜔𝕃10\omega_{\mathbb{L}}=10.

  • c.

    The Epileptic seizure recognition (ESR) dataset [47] with |D|=11,500𝐷11500|D|=11,500, h=179ℎ179h=179, and ω𝕃=2subscript𝜔𝕃2\omega_{\mathbb{L}}=2.

  • d.

    The default of credit card clients (CREDIT) [48] with |D|=30,000𝐷30000|D|=30,000, h=23ℎ23h=23, and ω𝕃=2subscript𝜔𝕃2\omega_{\mathbb{L}}=2.

  • e.

    The street view house numbers (SVHN) dataset [49] with colored images (3 channels), with |D|=600,000𝐷600000|D|=600,000, h=3×32×32ℎ33232h=3\times 32\times 32, and ω𝕃=10subscript𝜔𝕃10\omega_{\mathbb{L}}=10.

  • f.

    CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 with |D|=60,500𝐷60500|D|=60,500, h=3×32×32ℎ33232h=3\times 32\times 32, ω𝕃=10subscript𝜔𝕃10\omega_{\mathbb{L}}=10, and ω𝕃=100subscript𝜔𝕃100\omega_{\mathbb{L}}=100, respectively.

We convert SVHN to gray-scale to reduce the number of channels. In addition, we make the dimension of each weight matrix to the nearest power of 2 by padding zeros. As a result, we actually train the NN on the CREDIT, ESR, and MNIST datasets with the feature dimensions of 32, 256, 1024, respectively. Since SVHN is grayed out, the dimension of its features already meets the power of 2. On the other hand, we generate synthetic data to evaluate the scalability of the system, where we record the system performance under different features or the number of samples. For simplicity, we uniformly and randomly distribute all the above datasets to users. Note that the distribution of data among different users may affect the accuracy of the model, but this is orthogonal to the focus of this paper. Since Hercules is designed for general federated learning scenario, all existing processing strategies for data distribution can be seamlessly integrated into Hercules.

Appendix L Neural Network Structure

We use the following NN structures to train specific datasets.

  • a.

    We train a 2-layer fully connected NN with BCW, ESR and CREDIT data sets, where each layer contains 646464 neurons. Similarly, the same structure was used to test the cost of Hercules on the synthetic dataset.

  • b.

    We train a three-layer fully connected NN with 64 neurons in each layer for the MNIST and SVHN datasets.

  • c.

    We train two models for CIFAR-10 dataset. Specifically, (i) a CNN structure contains 222 convolutional layers (CV), an average pooling layer, a max pooling layer with kernel size of 2×2222\times 2, and two fully connected layer (FC) which contains 128128128 and 101010 neurons, respectively. We called this structure as CIFAR-10-N1. (ii) a CNN structure contains 444 CV with kernel size of 3×4343\times 4, an average pooling layer and a max pooling layer with kernel size of 2×2222\times 2, and 2 FC which contain 128128128 and 101010 neurons, respectively. We called this structure as CIFAR-10-N2.

  • d.

    For CIFAR-100, we train a CNN structure consisting of 666 CV with kernel size of 3×4343\times 4, an average pooling layer and a max pooling layer with kernel size of 2×2222\times 2, and 2 FC which contain 128128128 neurons for each layer.

We changed the number of filters from 3 to 16 for all CV layers. The number of global iterations used to train the above models is 100; 500; 600; 1000; 18,000; 16,800; 25,000 and 54,000 for BCW, CREDIT, ESR, MNIST, SVHN, CIFAR-10-N2, CIFAR-10-N1, and CIFAR-100, respectively. The local batch size of each user is set to 10, thus the global batch size is 100 for 10 users, and 500 for 50 users.

Appendix M Learning Extensions

M.1 Asynchronous distributed learning with uneven data distribution

In Hercules, we rely on all users online to complete the global update of the gradient under the ciphertext. However, Hercules also supports asynchronous neural network learning, which can be realized by the server only receiving data from users within a certain threshold time. In this case, the training of the neural network mainly benefits from the local data of users with good network status. Noted that the smooth execution of the distributed bootstrapping operation 𝐃𝐁𝐨𝐨𝐭𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐚𝐩𝐃𝐁𝐨𝐨𝐭𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐚𝐩\mathbf{DBootstrap} requires the participation of all users. This operation instead of being done in a centralized manner usually requires more computation and communication overhead.

In Hercules, we evenly distribute the data to each user for the simplicity of the experiment. In fact, the uneven distribution of users’ data and asynchronous gradient descent will inevitably affect the accuracy of the model. How to deal with these problems has been extensively studied [59, 60], which are orthogonal to this work. Note that our privacy protection method is independent of the distribution of user data and the way of gradient update. Hence, all existing works can be seamlessly integrated into Hercules.

M.2 Training on Other Neural Networks

In this work, we focus on deploying Hercules on MLPs and CNNs, and demonstrate the performance of our packing scheme and function approximation method under these NNs. For other structures, such as long short-term memory (LSTM)[61], recurrent neural network (RNN)[62] and residual neural network (ResNet) [63], Hercules needs to modify the local gradient update process according to their forward and backward pass operations. For example, ResNet has skip connections to skip certain layers, so after skipping a layer, the shape of the encrypted ciphertext should be aligned according to the weight matrix to be multiplied. This can be ensured by using the rotation function of CKKS (rearrange the slots of the ciphertext). We believe that these modifications are not significant. Although POSEIDON is tailored for MLPs and CNNs, in essence, Hercules can be used to quickly calculate any mathematical operation under ciphertext, which constitutes the main body of other neural network structures.

Appendix N Microbenchmarks of Hercules and POSEIDON

We present the microbenchmark cost of Hercules and POSEIDON in performing different functions. As shown in Table VIII, the bold font represents the overhead of Hercules. For experimental configurations, We consider the number of users N=10𝑁10N=10, the dimension of each sample is h=32ℎ32h=32, the number of neurons in each layer is 64 or with kernel size 3×3333\times 3, and the dimension of cyclotomic polynomial ring used in CKKS is set 𝒩=213𝒩superscript213\mathcal{N}=2^{13}. All the costs represent the processing of 1 sample per party.

We record the computation and communication costs (in an amortized way) of calculating FC, CV, FC backpropagation, CV backpropagation, and different activation functions in Hercules and POSEIDON. For the activation functions sigmoid and sofmax, Hercules and POSEIDON exhibit the same overhead because they both use the same function approximation method. For ReLU, since Hercules uses a 20 bit-precision composite polynomial to fit the original function, while POSEIDON simply uses a polynomial with a degree of 3 to approximate the original ReLU (using the least squares method), it makes the cost of Hercules larger than POSEIDON but derives a higher approximation accuracy. Note that given the same error bound, the time required to calculate the polynomial generated by the least square method under ciphertext is much longer than ours. For max pooling, POSEIDON replaces it with Chebyshev function interpolation, thereby obtaining a polynomial of degree 31 with a precision of 7 bits. Experimental results show that our 7-bit precision composite polynomial is much less expensive than POSEIDON. This is mainly due to the characteristics of composite polynomials. As discussed before, a composite function with degree of d​e​g​(G)𝑑𝑒𝑔𝐺deg(G) can be calculated with a complexity of O​(log⁡(d​e​g​(G)))𝑂𝑑𝑒𝑔𝐺O(\log(deg(G))), while the computation complexity of calculating any function G𝐺G is at least Θ​(d​e​g​(G))Θ𝑑𝑒𝑔𝐺\Theta(\sqrt{deg(G)}).

The operations in FC, CV and their backpropagation are mainly composed of matrix multiplication. As shown in Table VIII, Hercules is far superior to POSEIDON in terms of calculating homomorphic matrix multiplication. Specifically, POSEIDON adopts AP to achieve fast SIMD calculations. For the multiplication of two h×hℎℎh\times h-dimensional matrices, the complexity of the homomorphic rotation operation required by AP is maxi∈[𝕃]⁡(ωi×log⁡(h×ωi))subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝕃subscript𝜔𝑖ℎsubscript𝜔𝑖\max_{i\in[\mathbb{L}]}(\omega_{i}\times\log(h\times\omega_{i})). For Hercules, as shown in Table I, the complexity required for the matrix multiplication is only 3​h+5​h3ℎ5ℎ3h+5\sqrt{h}. Moreover, AP requires multiple copies and zero padding operations for each row or column of the input matrix, (depending on the number of neurons in each hidden layer, and the absolute value of the difference between the row or column dimension of the matrix and the corresponding hidden layer neuron. On the contrary, our method does not require additional element copying except for a small amount of zero padding in the initial stage to facilitate calculations. Therefore, Hercules obviously exhibits lower communication overhead.

Appendix O Storage Overhead

As shown in TABLE IX, we also count the storage overhead required for training each scheme on different datasets, where the storage overhead is mainly dominated by the size of the ciphertext that each user needs to save locally. We observe that the storage overhead required by Hercules on each dataset is much lower than that of POSEIDON. Since POSEIDON designs a alternating packing (AP) method to pack ciphertext in the encryption process, this leads to multiple copies and zero padding operations for each ciphertext, depending on the number of neurons in each hidden layer. On the contrary, our method does not require additional element copying except for a small amount of zero padding in the initial stage to facilitate calculations.

Appendix P Comparison with Other Prior Works

Beyond the HE-based schemes, a wealth of MPC solutions based on interaction between multiple servers have been proposed to design privacy-preserving neural network training and prediction frameworks. These solutions may be not practical in the real-world setting without multiple servers. Nevertheless, we still make a rough comparison between these works and Hercules to demonstrate the merits and demerits of each scheme. As shown in Table VII in the Appendix, MPC protocol with multiple servers relies on splitting the training task into two or more servers, where the servers are usually assumed to be non-colluding. Then, the state-of-the-art secret sharing methods, including arithmetic sharing [19], boolean sharing [8], and Yao’s garbled circuit [21] are carefully integrated to efficiently implement various mathematical operations under the ciphertext. It is computationally cost-effective, avoiding the high communication overhead among large-scale users. For example, given the MNIST dataset, we roughly compare the computational cost of Hercules, ABY3 [8], and XONN [58] in training the same network architecture. Here we use a three-layer architecture with 128 neurons in each layer. The number of users in Hercules is set to 3 and the global training epoch is set to 15. Experimental results show that Hercules requires a total of 24.3 hours to train such a model, while ABY3 and XONN need 1.02 and 0.58 hours, respectively. We remind that Hercules is operated in a different scenario (FL) and threat model from those MPC-based schemes. It supports more participants with collusion, and the cost only grows linearly with the number of users. In contrast, those MPC-based solutions require to outsource training tasks among limited computing servers, which may be impractical in some scenarios.
